byline.contributor: Hilary Stout contributed reporting from New York.

abstract: General Motors compensation fund announces approval of 100th death claim attributed to faulty ignition switches in company's cars; ignition-switch crisis has become one of deadliest in American automotive safety history and is particularly notorious since defect was hidden for almost a decade until GM recalled 2.6 million cars in 2014.
lead_paragraph: The new toll far exceeds the 13 victims that G.M. had said last year were the only known fatalities linked to ignitions that could suddenly cut off engine power and disable airbags.

headline.main: G.M.’s Ignition Switch Death Toll Hits 100
headline.print_headline: G.M.’s Ignition Switch Death Toll Hits 100

snippet: The new toll far exceeds the 13 victims that G.M. had said last year were the only known fatalities linked to ignitions that could suddenly cut off engine power and disable airbags.
